Must I still wear Time's heavy hours away!</br>Whose tedious moments pass reluctant by,</br>Each passing as it goes, with dull delay,</br>As tho' 'twould claim the requiem of a sigh,</br>And tear my heart's last hope from me: — Must I,</br>Apart from all my soul holds dear, still seek</br>To cheat myself of care, scarce knowing why;—</br>And feel my childish heart is all too weak,—</br>And cherish still a gloom which language cannot speak?

Must I — but wherefore do I still complain!</br>Who will regard my querimonious song?—</br>Ah!  there it is! — I sigh and sing in vain,</br>And chide my foolish heart, and say "'tis wrong</br>To murmur to indifferent ears so long."</br>But scarce this mild censure I repeat,</br>Ere my tumultuous feelings wildly throng</br>Across my prudent purpose, and defeat</br>My cold intentions with enthusiastic heat.

And now — (forgive me idol of my heart!</br>That I so often trespass on thine ear,—</br>My soul's dark spirit will not hence depart,</br>Till it has told its tale, tho' sad, sincere,—</br>And breath'd a sigh and shed, perhaps, a tear.</br>Oh!  then sweet angel of my peace, to thee,</br>Who art, of all things else, most priz'd — most dear,</br>I urge my prayer, — that thou wilt suffer me,</br>In this sad, lonely hour to speak my misery.

—This lonely hour — for tho' in "my mind's eye"</br>I see thee still, as I am wont to see,—</br>Yet I am sad, and ask my Reason, "why</br>In Fortune's dispensations, it should be,</br>That one who is so priz'd — so dear to me—</br>To whom my heart in tenderness could cling</br>And hang forever in sweet ecstasy,</br>Should be away — and separation bring</br>To my unhappy soul, an agonizing sting?"

Thus! — thus, thou angel of my peace and hope,</br>Did not the truth outstrip all words, I'd tell</br>What my heart feels — But language cannot cope</br>With the warm spirit of my soul; — nor well</br>Express the influence of my bosom's swell</br>Of rapture, when thy soul-sustaining eye,</br>In hasty and retiring glances, fell</br>Upon my vision; and in a hush'd sigh,</br>My inmost feelings breathe their eloquent reply.

But now no more! — I've trespass'd all too long!</br>My fugitive — my vagrant strain is o'er—</br>Forgotten soon, the Minstrel and his song</br>Shall pass away and trouble thee no more;</br>And thou shalt smile regardless as before,</br>When not one trace remains of him to tell,</br>Whom thou canst not revere, nor wilt deplore!</br>But ah!  I pause! — I feel my heart rebel!</br>Oh!  must I go from thee! — Oh! — must I say farewell!

Still!  still my heart, like one who gasps for life,</br>Clings to its last faint hope with trembling fear;</br>And still in agony, amidst its strife,</br>Feels all its peace, in darkness disappear!</br>Oh!  I could die for thee, thou art so dear!—</br>Or I could live, and be thy slave forever;</br>And e'en in wretchedness, if thou wert near,</br>Feel that life had no happier lot, — and never</br>Desire in weal or woe — in life or death, to sever!

But ah!  it is not — never it can be!—</br>Thou wilt not listen to my soul's deep tale!—</br>Peace and farewell, thou dear one! — peace to thee!</br>My song is o'er — my words cannot avail—</br>The wilderness shall hear my midnight wail,</br>And my poor heart, to thee too sternly true,</br>Till life's last impulse tremblingly shall fail,</br>Shall hold thy dear, dear image still in view!—</br>But now no more! — Forgive my foolish strain! — Adieu!</br>
